Intervention: Intervention in the field of education

The overall objective of these sessions was to provide information that would reduce participants' uncertainty about their illness or treatment, in order to improve their ability to adapt productively.

Participants attended nutrition education sessions of 2 hours, once a month for 4 months. Each session provided information/incentives on the establishment and achievement of goals for a healthy diet and on the benefits of positive thinking about adaptive treatment of problems and a healthy lifestyle.
Eligibility: Stage I or II of the disease
No more than 10 positive lymph nodes
A diagnosis for the first time
Less than 50 years at the time of diagnosis
Active treatment completed in the last 2 months
Must live less than 30 miles from Magee Women's Hospital, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
Other prior malignancies, except skin cancer
Results: • Depressive symptoms (measured by a 10-point short-term CESD) at the baseline stage, after the intervention (4 months after the intervention) and final follow-up (13 months after the intervention).
The scale of depression (CES-D) ranged from 0 (no depressive symptoms) to 24 (high rates of depressive symptoms) in the present sample.
Time frame: Reference data, follow-up after intervention (4 months after intervention) and final follow-up (13 months after intervention).
